We have written a little utility class RunATest.java which takes class name
and method name as argument. Its good that this change is incorporated in
new JUnit version.
  -----Original Message-----
  From: kentlbeck [mailto:kentbeck@...]
  Sent: Friday, April 12, 2002 10:44 AM
  To: junit@yahoogroups.com
  Subject: [junit] Re: using newInstance for TestCase


  --- In junit@y..., "pantinori" <pantinori@y...> wrote:
  > I am loading up my list of test cases from an xml file with
  something
  > like class and method.  Then using class.forname and
  > class.newinstance I would instantiate the TestCase.  I then wanted
  to
  > call TestCase.setName and then add the testcase to the testsuite.
  > unfortunately the newInstance fails because TestCase has a default
  > constructor that is not public.  :(  Is there a particular reason
  why
  > this is so?   Thanks for help.
  >
  > Paul Antinori

  If you check out the latest version from sourceforge, you will see a
  no-arg constructor. Erich and I had a perfectly good reason for not
  having a no-arg constructor which had one unfortunate flaw--it was
  complete bollocks. Now you can just call TestSuite.createTest
  (Class,String) to create a test with a given class and name.

  Kent
